bestBHT.bht: The divine call, which signifies the first step in personal salvation, brings about a transformation in our character, known as conversion. It is through this internal, effectual call that we are summoned out of our old, perishing condition and into a new, safe, and blessed life. The progression of being called, justified, and glorified is a manifestation of God's sovereign power and grace. This process, viewed as one complete and eternally completed salvation, leads us to the future glory that awaits us.

Henry Alford: And whom He foreordained, those He also called.
And whom He called, these He also justified.
And whom He justified, them He also glorified.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The word 'called'... always means 'internally, effectually, savingly called.' It denotes the first great step in personal salvation and answers to 'conversion.'

Only the word conversion expresses the change of character which then takes place, whereas this 'calling' expresses the divine authorship of the change, and the sovereign power by which we are summoned, Matthew-like, Zaccheus-like, out of our old, wretched, perishing condition, into a new, safe, blessed life.

Noble climax, and so rhythmically expressed! And all this is viewed as past; because, starting from the past decree of 'predestination to be conformed to the image of God's Son' of which the other steps are but the successive unfoldings—all is beheld as one entire, eternally completed salvation.
Albert Barnes: The connection is so certain that the one infallibly secures the other.
There is a connection infallible and ever existing between the predestination and the final salvation.
John Calvin: A participation of the cross is so connected with our vocation, justification, and, in short, with our future glory, that they can by no means be separated.
Calling here is to be distinguished from secret election, as being posterior to it.

Those whom God now, consistently with his purpose, exercises under the cross, are called and justified, that they may have a hope of salvation, so that nothing of their glory decays during their humiliation.
Philip Schaff: The call is effectual, is inseparably linked with predestination and justification in the unfolding of God’s gracious purpose."
Only those who believe are justified, but as throughout the subjective side is not presented. The whole passage is for the comfort of those who believe."
Moreover, the past tense is chosen to present the matter as necessary and certain, so much so that it can be spoken of as already accomplished.
Archibald T. Robertson: The step implied in εδοξασεν is both complete and certain in the Divine counsels."
The glorification is stated as already consummated, though still in the future in the fullest sense."
Called, justified, glorified. All first aorist active indicatives of common verbs.
John Gill: This predestination is of particular persons, who, in consequence of it, are called, justified, and glorified; it is the effect of divine grace, and entirely owing to it; it is the source of all the other blessings of grace, and is therefore placed at the head of them, and secures them all."
Their call is of grace, by special grace, to peculiar blessings of grace, and to a kingdom and glory; and this their calling is secured by predestination, and connected with glorification.

But eternal glory is here meant, which is what the apostle had been speaking of in the context; is what the elect are predestinated and called unto; and which their justification gives them a right and title to; and will consist in a likeness to Christ, in communion with him, in an everlasting vision of him, and in a freedom from all that is evil, and in an enjoyment of all that is good.
John Wesley: And whom he called — When obedient to the heavenly calling, Acts 26:19.
He also justified — Forgave and accepted.
Indeed grace, as it is glory begun, is both an earnest and a foretaste of eternal glory.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Romans 8:30, the progression of salvation is beautifully depicted. The verse speaks of the internal, effectual calling, which is a step towards conversion. It is through this divine call that we are summoned out of our old, perishing condition and into a new, blessed life. The calling is connected to predestination and justification, ensuring the infallible guarantee of final salvation. The word glorified is spoken of as already accomplished, even though it is still in the future. This entire process of being called, justified, and glorified is a manifestation of God's sovereign power and grace, leading us to the future glory that awaits us.

The progression of salvation is beautifully depicted in this passage. The internal, effectual call is the first step towards conversion, summoning us out of our old, perishing state and into a new, blessed life. This calling is connected to predestination and justification, ensuring the infallible guarantee of our final salvation. The word glorified is used, even though it is still in the future, emphasizing that the entire process is seen as one complete, eternally accomplished salvation. This journey culminates in the future glory that awaits us.

The divine call, which signifies the first step in personal salvation, brings about a transformation in our character, known as conversion. It is through this internal, effectual call that we are summoned out of our old, perishing condition and into a new, safe, and blessed life. The progression of being called, justified, and glorified is a manifestation of God's sovereign power and grace. This process, viewed as one complete and eternally completed salvation, leads us to the future glory that awaits us.

The divine call, which represents the first step in personal salvation, brings about a conversion, a complete change of character. It is through this internal, effectual call that we are summoned from our old, perishing state into a new, blessed life. The progression of being called, justified, and glorified is a testament to God's sovereign power and grace. Despite glorified being stated in the past tense, it is a future reality, emphasizing the consummation of our salvation. This process culminates in the future glory that awaits us.

The divine call, the first step in personal salvation, leads to a conversion, a profound change of character. This internal, effectual call rescues us from our old, perishing state and ushers us into a new, blessed life. The progression of being called, justified, and glorified showcases God's sovereign power and grace. Although glorified is spoken of in the past tense, it signifies a future reality, emphasizing the certainty and completeness of our salvation. Ultimately, this process culminates in the eternal glory that awaits us.
